sentence: The bakery owner fired his assistant because she kept burning the ___
original_sentence: The baker quit his job because he couldn't make enough ___
repair_explanation: Changed from the overused 'baker quitting' setup to a more specific scenario about burning food. This makes 'dough' more surprising since you don't typically think of burning money, creating a better punchline.
claudecode_explanation: "Dough" means money and bread dough. Burning dough/money isn't a common idiom though — 'burning through dough' would be better. The setup is fresh but the phrasing slightly misses.

sentence: The electrician was shocked when he couldn't handle the ___
original_sentence: The electrician was fired because he couldn't handle the ___
repair_explanation: Added 'shocked' to enhance the electrical theme and focused on 'current' as the strongest pun, since it works both as electrical current and current situation/workload.
claudecode_explanation: "Shocked" in the setup is already an electrical pun, and "current" adds another. Overstuffed with puns — having wordplay in both the setup AND blank reduces the surprise of the punchline.

sentence: The broke musician had to live off his ___
original_sentence: The musician couldn't pay rent so he was living on the ___
repair_explanation: Changed to 'live off his notes' which works more naturally than 'living on the notes' - both musical notes and banknotes make sense as something to live off of.
claudecode_explanation: "Notes" as musical notes and banknotes. "Live off his notes" works for both meanings. Clean double meaning, natural phrasing.

sentence: The gardener's career was really ___
original_sentence: The gardener was promoted because his work was ___
repair_explanation: Simplified to focus on 'blooming' as the strongest pun, and made the setup less predictable while maintaining the natural double meaning of both career success and plant growth.
claudecode_explanation: "Blooming" means flourishing and literally blooming (plants). Simple, clean, but extremely predictable for a gardener joke.

sentence: The optometrist's startup failed because he lacked ___
original_sentence: The eye doctor's business failed because he lost his ___
repair_explanation: Changed to 'startup' and 'lacked vision' to make the business context stronger and the pun less predictable, while 'vision' still works perfectly for both business foresight and eyesight.
claudecode_explanation: "Vision" means business foresight and eyesight. The "startup" context makes both meanings equally strong. Nice irony that an eye doctor lacks vision.

sentence: The librarian was overwhelmed because she had too much on her ___
original_sentence: The librarian was stressed because there was too much on her ___
repair_explanation: Changed 'stressed' to 'overwhelmed' to make the sentence flow more naturally with 'too much on her shelves' while maintaining the pun between library shelves and being overloaded with work.
claudecode_explanation: "Too much on her shelves" tries to rework the idiom "too much on her plate" but the substitution feels unnatural. Nobody says they have too much on their shelves to mean overworked.

sentence: The fisherman quit because his job wasn't bringing in enough ___
original_sentence: The fisherman quit because his job wasn't providing enough ___
repair_explanation: Changed 'providing' to 'bringing in' to create a more natural phrase that works better with both the fishing context (bringing in nets/catch) and financial context (bringing in income).
claudecode_explanation: "Net" works as both fishing net and net income. "Bringing in" is a natural verb for both contexts. "Catch" also has dual meaning. Solid, clean puns.

sentence: The geology student failed the exam because she didn't study ___
original_sentence: The geology professor was boring because he took everything for ___
repair_explanation: Switched from the tired 'taking for granite/granted' pun to 'hard' which works as both studying intensely and literally studying hard rocks. This creates a tighter, more natural double meaning.
claudecode_explanation: "Hard" is both a study adverb and a rock property, but it's simultaneously the straight AND punny answer — there's no surprise when the expected completion IS the pun.

sentence: The locksmith moved away because he wanted to turn over a new ___
original_sentence: The locksmith moved away because he wanted a fresh ___
repair_explanation: Changed to the idiom 'turn over a new leaf/key' because 'a fresh key' isn't a real expression. Now 'key' works as both the tool locksmiths use and as a replacement for 'leaf' in the common idiom about starting fresh.
claudecode_explanation: "Turn over a new key" replaces "turn over a new leaf" but the substitution feels forced. Nobody would naturally say "turn over a new key." The idiom hack doesn't land.

sentence: The clock maker was always late because he never had enough ___
original_sentence: The clock maker retired because he needed more ___
repair_explanation: Completely reframed the setup to create irony - a clock maker who makes time-telling devices is always late because he doesn't have enough time. This makes the pun more surprising and humorous rather than just obvious.
claudecode_explanation: "Time" for a clock maker is obvious but the irony of a clock maker not having enough time creates a nice paradox. The setup does the heavy lifting.

sentence: The arborist's marriage failed because his wife said he was too ___
original_sentence: The tree surgeon was stumped because the work was too ___
repair_explanation: Moved from work context to personal relationship, making the tree-related personality descriptions more surprising and emotionally resonant. 'Wooden' (emotionless) and 'shady' (untrustworthy) work better in this intimate context.
claudecode_explanation: "Shady" means untrustworthy and tree shade. "Wooden" means emotionally stiff and made of wood. Both work perfectly in a relationship context. Creative framing.

sentence: The wedding photographer was fired because the bride said her photos looked ___
original_sentence: The photographer had to quit because nothing was ___
repair_explanation: Shifted to a specific wedding scenario and focused on 'overexposed' which works as both a photography technical term and meaning too revealing/inappropriate. This creates a more scandalous and memorable punchline.
claudecode_explanation: "Overexposed" means too much light in photography and too revealing/scandalous. Both meanings work perfectly in the wedding photo context. Clever and slightly edgy.

sentence: The divorce attorney's wife left him because she found him completely ___
original_sentence: The lawyer's case was dismissed so he lost his ___
repair_explanation: Created ironic personal situation where a divorce lawyer gets divorced, and used 'objectionable' which works as both a legal courtroom term and meaning personally offensive. The irony makes the pun more satisfying.
claudecode_explanation: "Objectionable" means personally offensive and evokes the courtroom "Objection!" The irony of a divorce attorney getting divorced elevates this beyond a simple pun. Excellent.

sentence: The boat builder quit because his business was ___
original_sentence: The boat builder had to bail because things were ___
repair_explanation: The original had the pun in the setup ('bail') rather than the blank. Moving the wordplay to the answer makes 'sinking' and 'going under' work as both business failure and boat-related disasters.
claudecode_explanation: "Sinking" and "going under" both work as business failure and boat-related disasters. Clean but very predictable for a boat-themed joke.

sentence: The orchestra conductor's performance left the audience feeling ___
original_sentence: The orchestra conductor found his work quite ___
repair_explanation: The original was too predictable and had weak double meanings. Reframing around audience reaction makes 'moved' work as both emotionally affected and the physical conducting motions, creating a stronger pun.
claudecode_explanation: "Moved" means emotionally affected and physically moving (conducting gestures). "Stirred" works similarly. Both are decent but common emotional-physical puns.

sentence: The bicycle couldn't stand on its own because it was ___
original_sentence: The bicycle couldn't stand on its own because it was too ___
repair_explanation: The original missed the classic "two-tired" wordplay that sounds like "too tired." Changed to use the hyphenated version that clearly plays on both meanings: having two tires and being exhausted.
claudecode_explanation: "Two-tired" sounds like "too tired" and means having two tires. The pun is tight and classic, though extremely well-known. Good execution of an old favorite.

sentence: The chimney sweep's business was going up in ___
original_sentence: The chimney sweep's career was going up in ___
repair_explanation: Changed "career" to "business" and the context from failing to succeeding, so "going up" works positively for both the business growth and the literal direction smoke travels in chimneys.
claudecode_explanation: "Going up in smoke" idiomatically means failing, but the straight answers (value, profits, success) suggest the business is succeeding. The contradiction undermines the joke.

sentence: The cucumber farmer was always getting into a ___
original_sentence: The vegetable farmer was always in a ___
repair_explanation: Focused on one strong pun instead of three weak ones, and specified "cucumber farmer" to make the pickle connection more direct. "Getting into a pickle" works for both trouble and what you do with cucumbers.
claudecode_explanation: "Getting into a pickle" means getting into trouble, and cucumbers become pickles. Specifying "cucumber farmer" makes the connection tight and natural.

sentence: The electrician found the power outage completely ___
original_sentence: The electrician's work was absolutely ___
repair_explanation: Reframed around a power outage to make the electrical context more specific and meaningful. "Shocking" now refers to both the surprise of the outage and the electrical phenomenon, making the pun feel fresh rather than overused.
claudecode_explanation: "Shocking" means surprising and relates to electric shock. Overused pun word, but the power outage scenario gives it a slightly fresher context.

sentence: The personal trainer had trouble lifting his clients' ___
original_sentence: The gym owner couldn't work out the ___
repair_explanation: Completely reframed to focus on a trainer helping clients rather than a gym owner with business problems. "Lifting spirits" works perfectly for both emotional encouragement and the physical lifting done in gyms.
claudecode_explanation: "Lifting spirits" means boosting morale and physical lifting. Both meanings map perfectly to a personal trainer's job. Natural and satisfying.

sentence: The acupuncturist's practice was full of pressure ___
original_sentence: The acupuncturist's career had too many ___
repair_explanation: The original setup was too vague about what kind of career problems existed. The new version creates a clearer double meaning where 'pressure points' are both stressful situations and literal acupuncture targets.
claudecode_explanation: "Pressure points" works as both stressful situations in a practice and acupuncture pressure points. Tight compound pun where both words contribute.

sentence: The perfume maker's bankruptcy was no surprise - she'd lost her ___
original_sentence: The perfume maker had a nose for ___
repair_explanation: Changed from a predictable positive setup to a surprising negative one. Now the double meaning is sharper - losing your 'scents' (sense) explains the business failure, while literally losing your sense of smell would doom a perfume maker.
claudecode_explanation: "Scents" is a homophone for "sense." A perfume maker losing her scents/sense explains bankruptcy perfectly in both readings. Clean and surprising.

sentence: When the magician quit his job, he vanished without a ___
original_sentence: The magician got frustrated and disappeared without a ___
repair_explanation: The original was weak because 'trace' doesn't have a strong magic-specific meaning. 'Trick' works better as both a magic performance and something missing (like 'without a hitch'), plus it's more natural for someone to quit 'without a trick' up their sleeve.
claudecode_explanation: "Without a trick" tries to work as both magic performance and the phrase "without a trace/hitch," but "without a trick" isn't an established expression. The substitution doesn't land.

sentence: The baker was stressed because he was always in a ___
original_sentence: The baker felt the pressure because he was really in a ___
repair_explanation: The original was functional but I refined it slightly to make the stress connection clearer and more natural. Being 'always in a jam' flows better than 'really in a jam' for this context.
claudecode_explanation: "In a jam" means in trouble and refers to fruit preserves a baker would make. Classic idiom, works naturally, though predictable.

sentence: The cartographer got lost on his way to work, proving he was completely ___
original_sentence: The cartographer's career went off the ___
repair_explanation: Flipped from career troubles to personal irony. A cartographer who gets lost is both literally 'off the map' and figuratively hopeless, creating a more immediate and relatable contradiction.
claudecode_explanation: A cartographer who gets lost is inherently funny. "Off the map" works as both crazy/extreme and literally not on any map. Good irony in the scenario.

sentence: The music store was struggling financially so it had to sell all its ___
original_sentence: The music store was struggling so it was about to close its ___
repair_explanation: The original phrase 'close its notes/chords' wasn't a natural expression. Changed to 'sell all its notes/chords' which works both for musical items and financial promissory notes/debt agreements.
claudecode_explanation: "Notes" works as financial notes and musical notes, but "selling notes" is more natural for music than finance. "Chords" has no financial meaning at all.

sentence: The locksmith turned prison warden kept losing inmates because he couldn't keep them under ___
original_sentence: The prison warden was having a hard time keeping things under ___
repair_explanation: Added the locksmith background to make the pun more surprising and ironic. A locksmith-turned-warden who can't keep prisoners 'under lock and key' creates a professional contradiction that makes the failure funnier.
claudecode_explanation: "Under lock and key" means secure imprisonment, and a locksmith literally works with locks and keys. Fun character mashup creates the dual meaning.

sentence: The marine biologist was struggling to understand the ocean's ___
original_sentence: The marine biologist couldn't fathom the ___
repair_explanation: The original had the pun in 'fathom' rather than the blank. Moved the wordplay to the fill-in so 'depth' works both as physical ocean measurement and metaphorical complexity.
claudecode_explanation: "Depth" means profundity/complexity and ocean depth. Both meanings work but the pun is completely predictable for a marine biologist joke.

sentence: The baseball pitcher was surprisingly afraid of ___
original_sentence: The baseball player was a pitcher who was afraid of ___
repair_explanation: Minor adjustment to make the setup flow more naturally while preserving the double meaning of bats (baseball equipment and flying animals).
claudecode_explanation: "Bats" means baseball bats and flying mammals. Simple reversal of expectations — a pitcher afraid of bats is surprising and funny.

sentence: The carpenter did great work but always struggled with the ___
original_sentence: The carpenter nailed the interview but screwed up the ___
repair_explanation: The original had puns in the setup rather than the blank. Restructured so the wordplay is in the fill-in, where 'screws' and 'nuts' work as both carpentry hardware and slang for problems/crazy situations.
claudecode_explanation: "Screws" and "nuts" are both hardware and slang for messing up/being crazy. The combination works but the innuendo feels unintentional.

sentence: The astronomer's career prospects were looking ___
original_sentence: The astronomer's career was looking ___
repair_explanation: Added 'prospects were' to make the sentence flow more naturally and avoid the awkward phrasing. The puns still work perfectly - astronomers look 'up' at stars while careers look 'up' when improving, and 'stellar' means both excellent and star-related.
claudecode_explanation: "Stellar" means excellent and relates to stars. For an astronomer, career prospects looking stellar works perfectly in both senses.

sentence: The ice cream vendor was having a rough ___
original_sentence: The ice cream vendor had a meltdown during the ___
repair_explanation: Moved the pun from the setup to the blank where it belongs. Now 'melt' works as both a difficult situation and what happens to ice cream, while 'freeze' means being stuck/paralyzed and what ice cream should do.
claudecode_explanation: "Rough melt" and "rough freeze" are not natural expressions. Neither completes the sentence in a way that makes sense idiomatically. The pun fails.

sentence: The marathon runner was completely out of ___
original_sentence: The sprinter felt run down and out of ___
repair_explanation: Removed 'run down' from the setup since it was stealing the pun's thunder, and changed to 'marathon runner' to make the endurance context clearer. Now the pun words in the blank have stronger double meanings related to both exhaustion and running fuel/energy.
claudecode_explanation: "Out of gas" works for running out of energy and literal fuel, but the other options (breath, steam) are essentially straight answers too. The pun structure is muddled.

sentence: The firefighter's marriage was getting pretty ___
original_sentence: The fireman's relationship was always on the ___
repair_explanation: Changed the setup to avoid the obvious 'on fire' phrase and used 'heated/hot' which work better as both relationship descriptors (passionate/argumentative) and fire-related terms. This creates more natural wordplay than the original forced connection.
claudecode_explanation: "Heated" means angry and hot-temperature. "Hot" is similar. Both are obvious for a firefighter joke. Functional but zero surprise.

sentence: The novelist's latest work had a really strong ___
original_sentence: The author's story was bound to have a good ___
repair_explanation: Removed 'bound to' from the setup since it was redundant with the pun answers. Now 'binding' works as both book construction and story cohesion, while 'spine' means both the book's backbone and the story's central strength.
claudecode_explanation: "Binding" works as book binding and compelling/binding agreement. "Spine" means book spine and backbone/courage. Two clean puns — spine is the stronger one.

sentence: The banker was feeling unsteady and needed to check his ___
original_sentence: The banker wanted to check his ___
repair_explanation: The original was too predictable and obvious for a banker. Adding 'feeling unsteady' creates a clear physical context where 'balance' works both as checking one's physical balance and checking one's bank balance.
claudecode_explanation: "Balance" means financial balance and physical balance. Both meanings are equally strong in context. Clean, tight, natural phrasing.

sentence: The poker player lost his house but at least he still had a good ___
original_sentence: The poker player lost his house but kept his ___
repair_explanation: The original worked but was slightly awkward. Adding 'good' makes the sentence flow more naturally while maintaining the double meaning of poker hand and having a good situation/advantage despite losses.
claudecode_explanation: "Hand" means poker hand and physical hand. Losing his house (full house in poker?) but keeping a good hand adds a clever poker layer.

sentence: The coffee shop owner's energy was drained, so she decided to get a new ___
original_sentence: The coffee shop owner felt drained and needed a ___
repair_explanation: The original punny words were weak because 'filter' and 'refill' don't naturally complete 'needed a ___' in a personal context. Changing to 'get a new filter' works both for coffee equipment and metaphorically getting a fresh perspective/energy boost.
claudecode_explanation: "Filter" means coffee filter and a new perspective/filter on life. But "get a new filter" for changing one's outlook is a stretch. The coffee meaning dominates.

sentence: The carpet installer's career was completely ___
original_sentence: The carpet installer's career was really coming ___
repair_explanation: The original phrase 'coming unraveled' was awkward. Simplifying to 'completely unraveled' creates cleaner grammar while maintaining the double meaning of carpet fibers unraveling and a career falling apart.
claudecode_explanation: "Unraveled" means fell apart and carpet literally unraveling. The idiom maps perfectly to the profession. Clean and natural.

sentence: The soap maker was in a real ___
original_sentence: The soap maker finally came clean about his ___
repair_explanation: The original had the pun in the setup ('came clean') rather than the blank. Moving the wordplay to 'in a lather' creates a proper fill-in-the-blank pun that means both being agitated/worked up and literally being covered in soap foam.
claudecode_explanation: "In a lather" is a real idiom meaning agitated, and soap lather is literal. Both meanings work naturally for a soap maker. Nice use of a less common idiom.

sentence: The nuclear physicist's emotional breakdown happened right at ___
original_sentence: The nuclear physicist had a meltdown at ___
repair_explanation: The original was actually quite good but 'meltdown' in the setup made the pun too obvious. Changing to 'emotional breakdown' preserves the double meaning while making the nuclear workplace answers more surprising.
claudecode_explanation: "At work," "the reactor," and "the plant" — none of these have a meaningful double sense. A nuclear physicist's breakdown at a plant is literal, not punny.

sentence: After years of road work, the construction worker felt completely ___
original_sentence: The road construction worker felt paved over and ___
repair_explanation: The original 'paved over and ___' was clunky phrasing that didn't flow naturally. The new setup lets 'flat' and 'rolled' work as both emotional states and road construction terms.
claudecode_explanation: "Flat" means tired/depleted and road surface. "Rolled" means steamrolled emotionally and road rolling. Both work, with "rolled" being the stronger pun.

sentence: The mountain climber captain felt he was getting in over his ___
original_sentence: The ocean liner captain felt he was in deep ___
repair_explanation: The ocean liner setup was too obvious since captains are literally in deep water. Switching to mountain climbing makes the depth/summit answers unexpected while 'getting in over his head' remains a natural idiom.
claudecode_explanation: "In over his depth" isn't the right idiom (it's "out of his depth"), and "summit" doesn't fit the phrase at all. The sentence structure is broken.

sentence: The massage therapist felt like she was under constant ___
original_sentence: The submarine captain felt under too much ___
repair_explanation: The submarine setup was too literal since submarines are actually under pressure. A massage therapist deals with literal pressure on clients while also potentially feeling stressed, making the double meaning more clever.
claudecode_explanation: "Pressure" means stress and massage pressure. Both meanings are strong and the sentence reads naturally. Simple but effective.

sentence: The boxer found himself trapped in a tight ___
original_sentence: The painter found himself in a ___
repair_explanation: The painter setup was too predictable since 'painting yourself into a corner' is a common idiom. Boxing creates a fresh context where being in a 'corner' works both as a difficult situation and the literal corner of a boxing ring.
claudecode_explanation: "Tight corner" is both a boxing ring corner and the idiom for a difficult situation. Both meanings work but it's a common, unremarkable pun.

sentence: After the butcher slipped and fell backwards onto his own knife, customers said he really got ___
original_sentence: The butcher who backed into the meat grinder got a little behind in his ___
repair_explanation: Simplified the setup and changed the punchline to focus on being 'cut up' (emotionally upset vs. literally cut). Removes the overly graphic meat grinder imagery while keeping the dark humor more accessible.
claudecode_explanation: "Cut up" means physically injured and very amused (slang). Dark humor that works, but the overly graphic setup about falling on a knife is distracting.

sentence: The origami teacher decided the job was ___
original_sentence: The origami teacher's job was too ___
repair_explanation: The original 'too folding' was grammatically awkward. Changed to 'the job was folding' so 'folding' works both as origami technique and as slang for 'failing/going under.'
claudecode_explanation: "Folding" means quitting (folding one's hand) and paper folding in origami. Clean dual meaning — concise setup, satisfying punchline.

sentence: The boat repair shop was struggling until the owner finally caught ___
original_sentence: The boating store had its best ___
repair_explanation: Changed from a generic sales pun to nautical metaphors about success. 'Catching wind' or 'catching the current' both mean gaining momentum in business while using actual sailing terminology, making the connection more clever.
claudecode_explanation: "Caught wind" means heard about an opportunity and caught literal wind for sailing. Good use of the idiom in a nautical context.

sentence: The plastic surgeon refused to cut ___
original_sentence: The surgeon was very careful not to cut ___
repair_explanation: Changed to 'plastic surgeon refused to cut' which makes the corner-cutting idiom more impactful - a plastic surgeon who won't cut corners is being extra careful about aesthetics and results.
claudecode_explanation: "Cut corners" means taking shortcuts, and a plastic surgeon literally cuts. The irony of a surgeon who refuses to cut corners is sharp.

sentence: The yoga instructor found the new schedule too much of a ___
original_sentence: The yoga instructor was too flexible about the ___
repair_explanation: The original had the pun in the setup word 'flexible' rather than the blank. Reframed so 'stretch' works as both a yoga pose and meaning 'difficult challenge' in the phrase 'too much of a stretch.'
claudecode_explanation: "Stretch" means exaggeration/challenge and yoga stretching. Both meanings work naturally. Concise and clean.

sentence: The weightlifter couldn't decide whether to quit, so his coach told him to put his ___
original_sentence: The weightlifter decided to put his ___
repair_explanation: The original setup was incomplete and awkward. The new version creates a decision-making context where 'put his foot down' (make a firm decision) works naturally, while 'weights down' plays on the literal weightlifting action.
claudecode_explanation: "Put his foot down" and "put his weights down" — the blank needs to contain the punchline but neither phrase completes naturally. Structurally broken.

sentence: The pet store went bankrupt when all the parrots flew the ___
original_sentence: The pet shop owner was doing well until the birds flew the ___
repair_explanation: Made it more specific with 'parrots' and 'went bankrupt' to create a clearer cause-and-effect story, making the business failure more dramatic and the pun more satisfying.
claudecode_explanation: "Flew the coop" means escaped and is literal for birds in a coop. The specificity of parrots adds character. Both meanings are equally strong.

sentence: The detective found the mystery difficult to ___
original_sentence: The detective's work was hard to ___
repair_explanation: Changed from 'work was hard to' to 'mystery difficult to' because you crack cases/mysteries, not work. This makes 'crack' work both as solving a mystery and breaking something open.
claudecode_explanation: "Crack" means solve a mystery and crack open. Standard detective idiom, clean but unremarkable and overused.

sentence: The exhausted clockmaker had been working around the ___
original_sentence: The clock repairman worked around the ___
repair_explanation: Added 'exhausted' and 'had been working' to emphasize the continuous effort, making the 'around the clock' idiom feel more earned and the pun more natural.
claudecode_explanation: "Around the clock" means nonstop and literally around a clock. The irony of a clockmaker working around the clock is a nice paradox.

sentence: After years of cutting timber, the lumberjack realized he'd been so focused on his daily quota that he couldn't see the forest for the ___
original_sentence: The lumberjack felt he couldn't see the forest for the ___
repair_explanation: The original felt like just restating a proverb. The new setup creates a meaningful context about losing sight of environmental impact while being focused on individual trees, making the idiom feel fresh and relevant.
claudecode_explanation: "Can't see the forest for the trees" is a well-known idiom. The lumberjack context adds literal meaning, but the setup is far too long and the punchline is too familiar to surprise anyone.

sentence: The archaeologist was terrible at ___ anything recent
original_sentence: The archaeologist's dating life was ___
repair_explanation: The original pun was weak because 'ancient/old' describing a dating life doesn't create a strong double meaning. The new setup makes 'dating' the pun word itself, playing on both romantic dating and archaeological carbon dating.
claudecode_explanation: "Dating" means romantic dating and archaeological dating (carbon dating, etc.). The archaeologist being terrible at dating anything recent is a clever twist that makes both meanings work.

sentence: The roofer found the advanced mathematics course was over his ___
original_sentence: The roofer's career was over his ___
repair_explanation: The original setup was confusing because 'career was over his head' doesn't make grammatical sense. The new version creates a clear scenario where 'over his head' naturally means both 'too difficult to understand' and literally above where a roofer works.
claudecode_explanation: "Over his head" means beyond understanding and physically above (where roofers work). Both meanings work. Decent but predictable.

sentence: The egg farmer always told ___ jokes
original_sentence: The egg farmer's jokes were always ___
repair_explanation: The original phrasing 'jokes were cracked' was grammatically awkward. Changing it to 'told cracked jokes' makes the sentence flow naturally while maintaining the double meaning of cracked eggs and crazy/funny jokes.
claudecode_explanation: "Cracked" means crazy/hilarious jokes and cracked eggs. Simple, clean, natural phrasing. Gets the job done.

sentence: The candle shop's Black Friday sale was absolutely ___
original_sentence: The candle maker's schedule was completely ___
repair_explanation: Changed to a Black Friday sale scenario where 'lit' (exciting/busy) and 'wicked' (awesome) feel more natural as modern slang, while keeping the candle connection strong.
claudecode_explanation: "Lit" means exciting (slang) and candles being lit. "Wicked" means awesome (slang) and candle wicks. Two solid puns in one joke — the slang-to-literal mapping is clever.

sentence: The demolition company's first job completely ___
original_sentence: The demolition expert's career really ___
repair_explanation: Changed to 'first job' to make failure more believable and added 'imploded' as another demolition-related pun option, creating more variety in the wordplay.
claudecode_explanation: "Bombed" means failed spectacularly and explosive demolition. "Imploded" also works for both failure and demolition. The irony of a demolition company's job bombing is fun.

sentence: The wine maker's problems were slowly ___
original_sentence: The wine maker's problems were ___
repair_explanation: Added 'slowly' to make the time progression clearer and more natural. This strengthens how 'fermenting' and 'aging' work both as wine processes and as problems developing over time.
claudecode_explanation: "Fermenting" means brewing/building up and wine fermentation. "Aging" means getting worse over time and wine aging. Both are clean dual meanings.

sentence: The podiatrist's motto was 'always put your best ___'
original_sentence: The podiatrist always put his best foot ___
repair_explanation: Changed to a motto format to make the idiom completion feel more natural and less predictable. The setup now frames it as his professional philosophy rather than just describing his behavior.
claudecode_explanation: "Put your best foot forward" is the idiom, and a podiatrist specializes in feet. Clean and natural, though just dropping an existing idiom into a profession context.

sentence: The geologist's presentation rocked because his research was really ___
original_sentence: The geologist'site rocked because it was really ___
repair_explanation: Fixed the typo and awkward phrasing by making it about a presentation with research quality. This creates a clearer connection between 'solid' meaning both reliable research and literally describing rocks.
claudecode_explanation: "Rocked" in the setup is already a geology pun, and "solid/rock solid" adds more. Having puns in both the setup and blank overstuffs the joke and kills the surprise.

sentence: The glue factory worker's day got off to a ___
original_sentence: The glue factory worker got stuck in a ___
repair_explanation: Changed to 'sticky start' which is less predictable than the original options while maintaining the double meaning of adhesive properties and a problematic beginning.
claudecode_explanation: "Sticky start" combines sticky (glue) with rough start, but "sticky start" isn't a natural expression. The phrase feels manufactured.

sentence: The mirror salesman's biggest weakness was too much ___
original_sentence: The mirror salesman could really see himself in the ___
repair_explanation: Reframed as a character flaw to make 'self-reflection' work as both excessive introspection (a weakness) and literally looking at oneself in mirrors, creating a more surprising twist.
claudecode_explanation: "Self-reflection" means introspection and literally seeing yourself reflected in mirrors. Both meanings are equally strong. Tight, surprising, and natural. One of the best repairs.

sentence: The elevator mechanic's career was full of ___
original_sentence: The elevator mechanic's career had its ___
repair_explanation: Changed 'had its' to 'was full of' to make the sentence flow more naturally and feel less forced. The pun remains the same but now works better grammatically.
claudecode_explanation: "Ups and downs" means good and bad periods and elevator movement. Classic idiom play — clean but completely predictable.

sentence: The vegetarian was so energetic when discussing nutrition that people said he was full of ___
original_sentence: The vegetarian couldn't stop talking about food so people thought he was full of ___
repair_explanation: Reframed the setup to focus on being energetic rather than just talking, which naturally leads to 'full of beans' meaning both energetic/lively and literally full of the vegetarian staple food.
claudecode_explanation: "Full of beans" is a real idiom meaning energetic (or full of nonsense), and a vegetarian literally eats beans. The idiom usage is authentic and the connection is natural.

sentence: The pastry chef's winning streak meant she was really on a ___
original_sentence: The pastry chef was on a ___
repair_explanation: Added context about a winning streak to make 'on a roll' feel more natural and less predictable, while maintaining the clear double meaning with bread rolls.
claudecode_explanation: "On a roll" means doing well and bread/pastry rolls. Clean idiom play for a pastry chef. Standard but effective.

sentence: The railroad worker's weak excuse failed to gain any ___
original_sentence: The railroad worker's excuse didn't gain any ___
repair_explanation: Changed 'didn't gain' to 'failed to gain' for better flow and added 'weak' to emphasize why the excuse would fail to gain traction, making both meanings clearer.
claudecode_explanation: "Traction" means support/momentum and railroad/wheel traction. Both meanings work naturally in the sentence.

sentence: The chicken farmer's ambitious plans never seemed to ___
original_sentence: The chicken farmer's plans didn't ___
repair_explanation: Added 'ambitious' and changed to 'never seemed to' for better rhythm and to emphasize the ongoing failure, making both puns about unrealized potential feel more natural.
claudecode_explanation: "Hatch" means come to fruition and eggs hatching. "Fly" means succeed and what chickens famously can't do. Two decent puns with the chicken connection.

sentence: The florist's new business was surprisingly ___
original_sentence: The florist's business was ___
repair_explanation: The original was too predictable - of course a florist's business would be 'blooming.' Adding 'surprisingly' and flipping to negative straight answers creates actual surprise when the punny answer reveals the business is doing well despite expectations.
claudecode_explanation: "Blooming" and "rosy" both mean positive and relate to flowers. Clean but extremely predictable for a florist joke.

sentence: The seamstress was hanging by a ___
original_sentence: The thread maker was at the end of his ___
repair_explanation: Changed from 'thread maker' to 'seamstress' for clearer profession connection, and used 'hanging by a thread' idiom instead of 'end of rope' to make the thread connection more direct and natural.
claudecode_explanation: "Hanging by a thread" means barely surviving and sewing thread. Classic idiom that maps perfectly to seamstress work.

sentence: The blacksmith's timing was always ___
original_sentence: The blacksmith struck while the iron was ___
repair_explanation: The original just completed a famous idiom with no surprise. This version makes 'striking' the pun word, playing on both 'striking timing' (impressive) and the literal striking action blacksmiths do with hammers.
claudecode_explanation: "Striking" means remarkable and hammering metal on an anvil. Both meanings are active and vivid. Good for a blacksmith.

sentence: The coin collector hated ___
original_sentence: The coin collector thought change was ___
repair_explanation: Moved 'change' from the setup to the punchline where it belongs, and flipped the sentiment - now the irony is that a coin collector (who loves coins/change) hates change (alteration), creating a proper contradiction-based pun.
claudecode_explanation: "Change" means change in routine/life and monetary change (coins). Nice irony — a coin collector who hates change. Both meanings are strong.

sentence: The optometrist's business strategy was clearly ___
original_sentence: The optometrist's ideas were often ___
repair_explanation: Added 'clearly' for irony and flipped the straight answers to positive ones, making the punny answers more surprising since they contradict the positive setup while maintaining the vision/planning double meaning.
claudecode_explanation: "Shortsighted" means lacking foresight and a vision condition. For an optometrist's business strategy to be shortsighted is perfectly ironic. Clean dual meaning.

sentence: After dental surgery, the patient found the doctor's pills hard to ___
original_sentence: The dentist's advice was hard to ___
repair_explanation: The original had no real connection between dental advice and swallowing/digesting. Now it's about post-surgery medication, making both the literal difficulty swallowing pills and the figurative difficulty accepting medicine work together.
claudecode_explanation: "Hard to swallow" means hard to accept and literally difficult to swallow after dental surgery. The post-surgery context makes the literal meaning work perfectly.

sentence: When the cobbler got mugged, he was lucky the thieves didn't steal his ___
original_sentence: The shoe repairman had to save his ___
repair_explanation: Changed from a vague 'saving' scenario to a specific mugging situation where not losing your 'sole/soul' becomes both literal (shoe part) and figurative (spiritual essence), making the double meaning sharper and more surprising.
claudecode_explanation: "Sole" sounds like "soul" — thieves didn't steal his sole/soul. For a cobbler, sole is literal. "Heels" means bad people and shoe heels. Fun scenario but somewhat forced.

sentence: The surgeon-comedian had the audience in ___
original_sentence: The comedian had the audience in ___
repair_explanation: The original just used the idiom 'in stitches' without real double meaning. Adding 'surgeon' creates a professional context where 'stitches' means both uncontrollable laughter and literal medical sutures.
claudecode_explanation: "In stitches" means laughing hard and surgical stitches. The compound identity of surgeon-comedian makes both meanings fire simultaneously. Simple and effective.

sentence: The loan officer's jokes were so bad they earned zero ___
original_sentence: The banker's excuses just didn't add ___
repair_explanation: Shifted from excuses to jokes, making 'earning zero interest' work both financially (no profit) and socially (no engagement), while creating a more natural conversational flow than the awkward 'add interest' phrasing.
claudecode_explanation: "Interest" means audience engagement and financial interest. A loan officer's bad jokes earning zero interest — both meanings are equally strong. Clean.

sentence: After the plumber's divorce, his love life went down the ___
original_sentence: The plumber's business went down the ___
repair_explanation: Added a personal angle (divorce) to make the familiar 'down the drain' pun feel fresher and more emotionally resonant, while keeping the tight plumbing connection intact.
claudecode_explanation: "Down the drain" means wasted/ruined and literal plumbing drains. A plumber's love life going down the drain is fitting. Classic idiom play.

sentence: The glass maker's lies were completely ___
original_sentence: The window installer's future was ___
repair_explanation: Switched from future predictions to lies being exposed, making 'transparent/clear' work as both glass properties and the idea that his deception was see-through, creating a more clever and ironic twist.
claudecode_explanation: "Transparent" means obviously false and see-through like glass. A glass maker whose lies are transparent — the irony is perfect. Tight dual meaning.

sentence: The drummer was struggling to find his ___
original_sentence: The drummer couldn't beat the ___
repair_explanation: The original had the pun word 'beat' in the setup and created a logical contradiction (drummers should be able to beat drums). The repair moves the wordplay to the blank where 'rhythm/beat' works as both musical timing and life's natural flow.
claudecode_explanation: "Finding his rhythm/beat" means finding his groove in life and musical rhythm. But for a drummer, these words are so closely tied to the profession that there's little surprise.

sentence: The apiarist's pickup lines were absolutely ___
original_sentence: The bee keeper's business was really ___
repair_explanation: Changed from business success to pickup lines, making 'sweet' work as both honey-related and charming/romantic, while 'buzzing' suggests both bee sounds and creating excitement, adding romantic comedy to the bee theme.
claudecode_explanation: "Sweet" means charming and honey-sweet (bees make honey). "Buzzing" means exciting and bee buzzing. Decent but neither pun is particularly surprising for a beekeeper joke.

sentence: The math teacher needed therapy because she couldn't stop bringing work ___
original_sentence: The math book was sad because it had too many ___
repair_explanation: Changed from the overused 'sad math book' setup to a more relatable teacher scenario. The pun is tighter because 'bringing work problems home' naturally flows while maintaining the math/emotional problems double meaning.
claudecode_explanation: "Problems" means personal issues (therapy) and math problems. The ambiguity is perfect — she can't stop bringing her work problems home, and both readings make complete sense. Clever.

sentence: After the power outage, the lamp store owner's mood was surprisingly ___
original_sentence: The lamp store's future was looking ___
repair_explanation: Added the power outage context to create irony and make 'surprisingly bright/lit' more unexpected. The contrast between no power and a bright mood makes the pun more clever and less predictable.

sentence: The loan officer's dating life suffered because he kept calculating the ___
original_sentence: The banker quit because he lost all ___
repair_explanation: Shifted from a generic 'banker quits' to a more specific dating scenario. 'Calculating interest' works both as romantic interest and financial interest, creating a fresher angle on the classic banking pun.
claudecode_explanation: "Interest" means romantic interest and financial interest rate. Same pun as joke 106 but in a dating context. Repetitive within this set.

sentence: The stand-up comedian avoided breakfast meetings because eggs always ___
original_sentence: The eggs refused to trade jokes because they might ___
repair_explanation: Reframed as a comedian's perspective to make the setup more natural and surprising. 'Eggs always crack' works as both heckling/laughing at jokes and physically breaking, with better comedic timing.

sentence: The comedian loved gardening because it helped him develop new ___
original_sentence: The comedian loved gardening because it always gave him new ___
repair_explanation: Changed 'gave him new' to 'helped him develop new' to make 'plots' sound more natural in comedy context, since comedians develop plots/storylines rather than just receive them.
claudecode_explanation: "Plots" means comedy plots/storylines and garden plots. Developing new plots works naturally in both contexts. Good dual meaning.

sentence: The electrician's argument was convincing because it carried a lot of ___
original_sentence: The electrician’s argument was convincing because it carried a lot of ___
repair_explanation: This joke is already well-crafted and doesn't need repair. The double meaning of 'charge' (electrical charge and argumentative force) works naturally in both contexts.
claudecode_explanation: "Charge" means emotional force/persuasiveness and electrical charge. Both meanings are strong in context. Clean and natural.

sentence: The opera singer's apartment hunt failed because every place felt too ___
original_sentence: The musician got fired because his performance was always a bit too ___
repair_explanation: Changed from a firing scenario to apartment hunting, making 'too flat' work as both lacking character/boring and being a flat (apartment). The opera singer context maintains the musical connection while creating a fresh angle.
claudecode_explanation: "Flat" means an apartment (British English) and off-pitch/flat singing. An opera singer finding every place too flat — the dual meaning is brilliant and unexpected.

sentence: The geometry teacher loved the beach because it had so many perfect ___
original_sentence: The geometry teacher left the beach because there were too many ___
repair_explanation: The original had no clear reason why a beach would have 'too many angles.' The repair makes both meanings work: beaches naturally have many visual angles/perspectives, and a geometry teacher would appreciate finding perfect angles in nature.

sentence: The baker quit because the job required too much ___
original_sentence: The baker changed careers because the hours were too ___
repair_explanation: The original 'hours were too kneading' was grammatically broken. Changing to 'required too much kneading' makes it grammatically correct while preserving the kneading/needing homophone pun.
claudecode_explanation: "Kneading" sounds like "needing" but "too much kneading" doesn't naturally map to "too much needing." The homophone connection is there but the sentence doesn't support both readings.

sentence: The baker's financial plan was simple: make more ___
original_sentence: The baker’s financial plan was simple: make more ___
repair_explanation: This joke was already well-constructed with a clean setup and natural double meaning. No repair needed - both the money slang and baking ingredient meanings work perfectly.
claudecode_explanation: "Dough" means money and bread dough. This is the most overused pun in comedy and appears multiple times in this set. No freshness.

sentence: The lawyer's comedy career flopped because all his material was too ___
original_sentence: The lawyer kept his jokes short because he specialized in the ___
repair_explanation: Changed from a positive trait (specializing in briefs) to a comedy failure (material too brief), making the irony sharper. The contradiction between needing longer material for comedy success versus lawyer's habit of being brief creates better tension.
claudecode_explanation: "Brief" means short/concise and a legal brief. A lawyer's comedy material being too brief — both meanings work perfectly and the career crossover adds irony.

sentence: The dentist hired candidates who had experience with ___
original_sentence: The dentist’s favorite type of job candidate was someone with good ___
repair_explanation: The original tried to force 'fillings' to sound like 'feelings' but they're too different. The repair focuses on the literal meaning - dentists actually work with fillings, making it a natural job requirement rather than a forced homophone.
claudecode_explanation: "Fillings" means dental fillings and filling positions/roles. But "experience with fillings" only naturally reads as dental fillings. The hiring meaning is a stretch.

sentence: The guitarist loved traffic because it gave him time to practice his ___
original_sentence: The musician hated driving to rehearsal because of all the ___
repair_explanation: Flipped from hating traffic to loving it, creating an unexpected positive spin. Now the musician benefits from traffic jams to practice musical jams, making both meanings work harmoniously rather than one being negative.
claudecode_explanation: "Jams" means traffic jams and musical jam sessions. A guitarist loving traffic because of jams — clever scenario that makes both meanings work simultaneously.

sentence: The drummer was great at making ___
original_sentence: The drummer got hired because he had excellent ___
repair_explanation: The original had no real double meaning since 'beats' only worked in the musical sense. Now 'beats' works as both drum rhythms and as slang for making/creating something cool or impressive.
claudecode_explanation: "Beats" as drum beats and... making beats. There's no real second meaning here — both uses are essentially musical. This isn't a pun, just a literal statement.

sentence: The librarian's romance novels were gathering dust on the ___
original_sentence: The librarian loved suspense because it always kept her on the ___
repair_explanation: The original forced connection between 'on the shelf' and suspense didn't work. Now 'on the shelf' works both literally (where books sit) and idiomatically (unused/neglected), creating a proper double meaning about neglected romance novels.

sentence: The chef quit because he couldn't stand the ___
original_sentence: The chef got promoted because he could handle the kitchen ___
repair_explanation: The original was too obvious since 'kitchen heat' is already a common idiom. By changing to 'couldn't stand the heat,' it references the famous saying while maintaining the literal/figurative double meaning more cleverly.
claudecode_explanation: "Couldn't stand the heat" references the saying "if you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen." Classic, well-known, and the chef context makes it literal too.

sentence: The carpenter's band never got popular because their music was too ___
original_sentence: The carpenter’s favorite music was anything with a good ___
repair_explanation: The original 'saw' connection was forced and obscure. 'Wooden' works much better as both a carpentry material and as meaning stiff/awkward performance, creating a natural double meaning for why a carpenter's band might fail.
claudecode_explanation: "Wooden" means stiff/uninspired (performance) and literally made of wood. Both meanings work well in the carpenter-musician crossover.

sentence: The fisherman stayed optimistic because he knew there was always another ___
original_sentence: The fisherman stayed optimistic because he always focused on the ___
repair_explanation: The original 'focused on the catch' was awkward phrasing that didn't clearly convey optimism. 'Another catch' works both as another fish to catch and as another opportunity/chance, making the optimism clear.
claudecode_explanation: "Catch" means opportunity/good thing and fishing catch. "Always another catch" works as both optimism about fish and about life. Clean but mild.

sentence: The house painter was so easygoing because he always went with the ___
original_sentence: The painter got along with everyone because he always went with the ___

sentence: The artist was great at relationships because he knew how to ___ people in
original_sentence: The artist was great at relationships because he knew how to ___
repair_explanation: Added 'people in' to complete the phrasal verb 'draw in,' making the relationship meaning clearer while maintaining the artistic double meaning. Now both senses work naturally in the sentence.
claudecode_explanation: "Draw people in" means attract/engage and literally drawing (art). Both meanings work well and the phrasing is natural.

sentence: The therapist who treated musicians always took detailed ___
original_sentence: The therapist who treated musicians said most problems came down to ___
repair_explanation: Changed from the awkward 'problems came down to notes' to 'took detailed notes,' which is natural phrasing that works perfectly for both therapy notes and musical notes.
claudecode_explanation: "Notes" means therapy session notes and musical notes. A therapist treating musicians taking detailed notes — both readings are natural and simultaneous.

sentence: The detective specialized in bakery thefts because every case left a clear ___
original_sentence: The detective loved bread cases because every clue left a clear ___
repair_explanation: Changed 'bread cases' to 'bakery thefts' for clearer context, and 'left a clear crumb' works better than the original since crumb trails are actual evidence in bakery crimes while also being detective clues.
claudecode_explanation: "Crumb" is a trail/clue and literal bread crumbs. The bakery theft detective concept is fun but "left a clear crumb" isn't natural phrasing — it should be "crumb trail."

sentence: The cameraman never panicked during chaos because he always stayed in ___
original_sentence: The cameraman stayed calm because he always kept things in ___
repair_explanation: The original was too predictable with 'kept things in focus.' Changed to 'stayed in focus' which sounds more natural and makes the pun less obvious while maintaining both meanings.
claudecode_explanation: "In focus" means concentrated/calm and camera focus. Both meanings work well for a cameraman staying composed during chaos.

sentence: The tailor was terrible at debates because his arguments always came ___

repair_explanation: The original failed because 'strong seam' has no meaning in argument contexts. 'Unraveled' works perfectly - arguments unravel (fall apart) and seams literally unravel in tailoring.
claudecode_explanation: "Came unraveled" means fell apart logically and fabric unraveling. Classic idiom that maps perfectly to a tailor.

sentence: The musician's relationship ended badly - they were constantly out of ___

repair_explanation: Simplified the setup to make 'out of tune' flow more naturally. The original was wordy and the pun works better with 'constantly out of tune' describing ongoing relationship discord.
claudecode_explanation: "Out of tune" means not in sync (relationship) and musically off-key. Both work but it's a very predictable musician relationship joke.

sentence: The cow became a philosopher because she loved to ___

repair_explanation: Changed from goat/cud to cow/ruminate. 'Ruminate' perfectly means both literal chewing (what cows do) and deep thinking (what philosophers do), creating a natural double meaning.

sentence: The chess master's risky strategy backfired - it was a terrible ___

repair_explanation: The original was fine but predictable. Reframed to show a failed gambit, making both chess and general strategy meanings work while adding narrative tension about the outcome.

sentence: The baker's favorite comedy shows were the ones that really made the audience ___
original_sentence: The baker’s favorite kind of comedy was anything that rose to the ___
repair_explanation: The original forced 'yeast' into an unnatural phrase. Changed to use 'rise' which works both as making an audience 'rise' (stand up in applause/laughter) and connects to bread rising in baking.
claudecode_explanation: "Rise" means stand up in excitement and bread rising. The audience rising connects to comedy, and baker rising connects to baking. Decent crossover.

sentence: The fisherman avoided certain restaurants because the waiters always tried to reel him ___

sentence: The accountant's camping hobby was expensive because she always bought the most expensive ___

sentence: The comedian quit the bakery because his jokes there always seemed to ___

sentence: The orchestra director loved having a good ___

repair_explanation: Changed from negative 'worst enemy' to positive context since musical rests aren't bad. Now 'rest' works as both a musical notation and taking a break, making both meanings positive.
claudecode_explanation: "Rest" means relaxation and a musical rest (a pause notation). Both meanings work naturally for an orchestra director.

sentence: The cat became a lawyer because it was always good at making valid ___

sentence: The dog became a therapist because it was great at helping people work through their ___

repair_explanation: The original 'seeing both barks' made no sense in any context. Changed to use 'ruff' which sounds like 'rough' (as in rough patches/problems) while being a dog sound, creating a proper double meaning.

sentence: The bee started a small company and called it a buzzing ___

sentence: The geologist's comedy career took off because all his jokes were ___
original_sentence: The geologist’s jokes were solid because they always had a good ___
repair_explanation: The original was decent but predictable with 'foundation.' Changed to use 'gneiss' (a type of rock) which sounds like 'nice' - making his jokes both literally rock-related and colloquially good.

sentence: The beer critic quit philosophy school because he preferred studying the ___
original_sentence: The bartender became a philosopher because he spent years pondering the ___

sentence: The fisherman opened a stationery shop and said he was really ___ in customers
original_sentence: The fisherman opened a stationery shop and said the sales were really ___

sentence: The fish got a job at the produce market because it was great with ___
original_sentence: The fish got a job in accounting because it was great with ___

sentence: The baker got promoted because his work always rose to the ___
original_sentence: The baker got promoted because he always delivered under ___

sentence: The poet became a sailor because he loved working with ___

sentence: The electrician's favorite kind of story had a powerful ___
original_sentence: The electrician’s favorite kind of story had a shocking ___

claudecode_explanation: "Charge" means emotional power and electrical charge. Same pun as joke 124. Clean but repetitive within this set.

sentence: The librarian loved reading because she could never stop after one ___

repair_explanation: The original connected dieting to reading through 'chapter,' but chapters aren't diet-related. Changed to reading context where 'chapter' naturally fits both meanings - book sections and the inability to stop reading.

sentence: The gardener refused to gossip because he didn't want to spread ___
original_sentence: The gardener refused to gossip because he didn’t want to spread ___

sentence: The barber quit law school because he preferred making a clean ___
original_sentence: The barber loved debate because he always made a sharp ___
repair_explanation: Created a career change narrative from law to barbering, with 'clean cut' working both as a precise legal severance and a neat haircut. This setup feels more natural and the double meaning is tighter.

original_sentence: The iron was stressed out because it had too many ___
repair_explanation: Added the HR complaint angle to make it more absurd and workplace-focused, strengthening 'wrinkles' as both job complications and the literal thing an iron removes.
claudecode_explanation: "Wrinkles" means problems/complications and fabric wrinkles. A clothing iron dealing with too many wrinkles — both meanings are natural and the HR complaint adds humor.

sentence: The farmer always said the secret to success was to make ___ while the sun shines
original_sentence: The farmer woke up early every morning because he had to make ___
repair_explanation: The original setup didn't complete the familiar idiom 'make hay while the sun shines.' The repaired version uses this complete phrase, making 'hay' work both as the literal farm product and as part of the well-known expression about seizing opportunities.
claudecode_explanation: "Make hay while the sun shines" is an existing proverb. Adding a farmer just makes it literal. The joke IS the proverb — there's no surprising recontextualization.

sentence: The door salesman was so good at his job because he knew exactly when to ___
original_sentence: The door salesman was the best closer because he always knew how to ___
repair_explanation: The original telegraphed the punchline by using 'closer' in the setup. Removing that word and changing to 'when to ___' creates surprise while maintaining both meanings of 'close' (finalizing sales and shutting doors).
claudecode_explanation: "Close" means close a sale and close a door. Both meanings work perfectly for a door salesman. Clean, tight, satisfying.

sentence: The astronaut kept getting dumped because his relationships always felt ___
original_sentence: The astronaut's girlfriend left him because he was too emotionally ___
repair_explanation: Changed from the obvious 'distant' to 'spacey' which works better as slang for being absent-minded/unfocused while connecting to space travel. The framing around repeated relationship failures makes it funnier.
claudecode_explanation: "Spacey" means distracted/absent-minded and space-related. An astronaut being spacey — both meanings work. Fun though predictable.

sentence: The fisherman never worried about his problems because he knew they'd eventually ___
original_sentence: The fisherman's life had its ups and downs but he stayed on an even ___
repair_explanation: Switched from the clichéd 'even keel' setup to use 'scale' which means both to climb/overcome something and fish scales. The optimistic framing about problems resolving feels more natural and conversational.
claudecode_explanation: "Scale" should mean grow bigger and fish scales, but "problems eventually scale" meaning they resolve doesn't work. The intended meaning is unclear.

sentence: The blood bank went out of business because it lost all its ___
original_sentence: The newspaper went out of business because it lost all its ___
repair_explanation: The original used 'circulation' too literally for newspapers. Changing to 'blood bank' creates a genuine double meaning where 'circulation' refers both to blood flow (medical) and customer/donor distribution (business).
claudecode_explanation: "Circulation" means customers/business circulation and blood circulation. A blood bank losing circulation — both meanings are equally strong. Clever.

sentence: The refrigerator was a great horror movie host because every story gave the audience ___
original_sentence: The refrigerator was a great comedian because every joke gave the audience ___
repair_explanation: Changed from comedian to horror movie host because 'chills' naturally describes both the cold from a refrigerator and the thrilling fear response to horror stories, making both meanings work perfectly together.
claudecode_explanation: "Chills" means fear/horror and refrigerator cold. A refrigerator hosting horror movies that give chills — both meanings work and the scenario is fun.

sentence: The scuba instructor's students loved her because she never made them feel ___
original_sentence: The scuba diver was always calm because no problem was too ___
repair_explanation: Changed from 'deep problems' to 'shallow feelings' which flips the water depth pun while using shallow's meaning of superficial/inadequate. The teaching context makes the emotional meaning stronger and more relatable.
claudecode_explanation: "Shallow" means superficial/inadequate and shallow water. A scuba instructor who never makes students feel shallow — both meanings are strong. Clever inversion of the expected 'deep' pun.

sentence: The hot air balloon operator was terrible at his job because he always ___
original_sentence: The balloon was depressed because his friends kept letting him ___
repair_explanation: Completely reframed to use 'cracked under pressure' which works for both psychological stress and the literal air pressure that inflates balloons. The professional incompetence angle is funnier than the friendship disappointment setup.
claudecode_explanation: "Cracked under pressure" means couldn't handle stress and balloons cracking from air pressure. Both meanings work for a balloon operator. Multi-word pun but effective.

sentence: The airplane mechanic was frustrated because his career never got off the ___
original_sentence: The airplane mechanic was depressed because his ideas never got off the ___
repair_explanation: Changed 'ideas' to 'career' and 'depressed' to 'frustrated' to make the setup more personal and relatable, while keeping the strong double meaning of 'ground' as both literal takeoff surface and metaphorical starting point for success.
claudecode_explanation: "Got off the ground" means never started and planes literally leaving the ground. An airplane mechanic whose career never got off the ground — both meanings are perfect. Clean idiom play.

sentence: The tornado was a terrible therapist because all his advice was ___
original_sentence: The tornado's personal life was a mess because everything was always ___
repair_explanation: Reframed from personal life to professional role as therapist, making 'twisted' work as both literally describing tornado motion and figuratively describing bad/distorted advice, creating a more focused and surprising pun.
claudecode_explanation: "Twisted" means wrong/perverse and tornado twisting. Both meanings are natural for a tornado therapist.

sentence: The baker quit his day job to become a loan officer because he already knew how to make ___
original_sentence: The baker was also a great banker because he understood ___
repair_explanation: Changed from 'bread' to 'dough' which is more natural slang for money and literally what bakers work with. Also reframed the setup to make the career transition more logical and natural.
claudecode_explanation: "Dough" means money and bread dough. The fifth dough pun in this set. Even the career-switch angle can't save this overused pun word.

sentence: The telephone was ignored all day because nobody answered its ___
original_sentence: The telephone was sad because nobody picked up on its ___
repair_explanation: Changed 'picked up on' to 'answered' to make both meanings work more naturally - answering rings (phone calls) and answering rings (responding to signals). This creates clearer parallel meanings.
claudecode_explanation: "Rings" means phone ringing and... just phone ringing. There's no second meaning. A telephone's rings being ignored is purely literal.

sentence: The fence couldn't make up its mind and remained sitting on the ___
original_sentence: The fence was completely undecided and stuck on the ___
repair_explanation: Used the established idiom 'sitting on the fence' (being undecided) and changed it to 'sitting on the post' so both meanings work - literally sitting on a fence post, and figuratively remaining undecided about an issue.
claudecode_explanation: "Post" as in fence post and "sitting on the post" trying to reference "sitting on the fence." But the idiom is about the fence, not the post. The substitution doesn't land.

sentence: The elevator operator's jokes were brilliant because they worked on so many ___
original_sentence: The elevator operator's jokes were bad because they worked on too many ___
repair_explanation: Changed 'bad' to 'brilliant' to fix the logical contradiction - jokes that work on multiple levels are good, not bad. Now both meanings align: elevators work on multiple floors/levels, and sophisticated jokes work on multiple levels of meaning.
claudecode_explanation: "Levels" means layers of meaning and elevator levels/floors. An elevator operator's jokes working on many levels — both meanings are equally strong and the meta-humor about jokes having levels is delightful.
